section.title: Projects, Lines and Flows
section.para: The processing of a seismic data is carried out by processing flows. A processing flow is a chain of programs, which sequentially operates on an input data to produce an output data from it. For example, processing flows can be assembled to accomplish tasks like spike deconvolution, ground-roll atenuation, NMO correction, and so on.

In GêBR, processing flows are referenced as Flows. The complete processing of a seismic data (also known as a seismic line, in 2D case) involves several processing flows. The set of processing flows is referenced as a Line in the GêBR interface. Furthermore, it is common to have many seismic lines acquired on a target area. A set of seismic lines is known as a Project, in GêBR.
In summary, GêBR has three levels organization, from top to bottom:

listitem.para: Project: It is a set of Lines. A Project has only few basic information and is used to cluster lines related somehow.

Line: It is a set of Flows. During the setup of the Line, some important choices have to be made, mainly concerning the organization of the processing products (intermediate data, figures, tables, etc) produced during the processing of a seismic line.
Flow: It is a sequence of programs, designed to accomplish a specific task, in the course of the processing the seismic data.

section.para: Thus, before creating and executing Flows, it's necessary to create at least one Project owning one Line. , and explain how this is accomplished.
To assemble a Flow, the user has not only to select the programs, but also configure them properly, through their parameters. Once the Flow is ready, it is time to actually execute it.

section.title: GêBR players
section.para: The GêBR set of tools is composed by three main player categories: GêBR (the interface itself), Maestros, and working machines. But who are those guys?

The GêBR interface, sometimes refered as GêBR only, is the graphical interface with whom the user interacts with to build processing flows, execute them, inspect results, etc. Usually, this interface is installed and is running in the machine user has physical contatct with.

Through GêBR, it is possible to take advantage of as many machines as the user has access, to run processing flows. Those machines are referenced as working machines (or sometimes, as servers). They may be local, meaning the user is physically using them, or remote, meaning the user has access to them through the network. No matter where the machines are, they are equally treated by GêBR, which means that the user does not have to care about that.

However, GêBR does not talk directly with the working machines. This communication is established through another player, the Maestro. It acts as a coordinator of the working machines. Without interference, Maestro collects information about the state of each working machine and ranks them according to their capabilities and available resources at time. Therefore, Maestro can take smart decisions about which machines are best suited to run the job.
The working machines put their computational power at disposal of the Maestro. Under Maestro's coordination the working machines can even cooperate to conclude processing jobs fasters.

When the user decides to execute a flow, GêBR sends this request to the Maestro, giving rise to a job. However the Maestro does not execute the job itself. Indeed, it dispatches the job to some of the working machines, under its control. Besides, Maestro collects the results and all information about the job, sending them back to GêBR, where they are presented to the user.
This communication process, despiste complex, is completely transparent to the user, which can concentrate on processing seismic data, leaving all technical details to GêBR.
